comments:
This intermediate-level course in macroeconomics and the global economy, including topics in monetary and international economics, aims to provide a unified framework for understanding macroeconomic events and policy. The course analyzes the determinants and behavior of employment, production, demand and profits; inflation, interest rates, asset prices, and wages; exchange rates and international flows of goods and assets; including the interaction of the real economy with monetary policy and the financial system. 

Student opinions about this class were mixed. While some called the class “amazing” and full of “relevant current information,” others found the lectures “boring” and the slides “straight out of the book.”

Most students enjoyed Professor Kurmann’s teaching. One student called him “one of the best professors I have ever had,” and another mentioned that Professor Kurmann “likes to really challenge his students to think about real macroeconomic issues.” Others emphasized his ability to stimulate student interest and his accessibility out of class. 

Many students indicated that they would have liked more guidance on problem sets and exam material. “Classes in the future should emphasize more of the difficult algebraic concepts if they will be tested,” one student commented, adding, however, “I am glad that I took this class, and would have done so again if given the opportunity.”

Student opinions about this class were mixed. While some called the class “amazing” and full of “relevant current information,” others found the lectures “boring” and the slides “straight out of the book.”

Most students enjoyed Professor Kurmann’s teaching. One student called him “one of the best professors I have ever had,” and another mentioned that Professor Kurmann “likes to really challenge his students to think about real macroeconomic issues.” Others emphasized his ability to stimulate student interest and his accessibility out of class. 

Many students indicated that they would have liked more guidance on problem sets and exam material. “Classes in the future should emphasize more of the difficult algebraic concepts if they will be tested,” one student commented, adding, however, “I am glad that I took this class, and would have done so again if given the opportunity.”

This intermediate-level course in macroeconomics and the global economy, including topics in monetary and international economics, aims to provide a unified framework for understanding macroeconomic events and policy. The course analyzes the determinants and behavior of employment, production, demand and profits; inflation, interest rates, asset prices, and wages; exchange rates and international flows of goods and assets; including the interaction of the real economy with monetary policy and the financial system. 

While students generally found the application of course concepts to the current recession especially interesting, a few students did not find the material completely relevant to real-world concepts. Some students pointed to the outside readings as “beneficial complements” to course material and the textbook. 

Many students praised Professor Caskey for his dedication to the class and his willingness to address students’ issues. According to one student, “The day before our first midterm there was a snow-day. Caskey walked 25 blocks through the snow from his house to give us a review session even though the school was closed.” Another mentioned that the professor “clearly knows the material incredibly well and at a very in-depth level, yet he was able to communicate complex topics in simple, easy to understand terms.” 

Several students commented that the lectures could have been more interactive, and the final project was “vague and poorly structured,” but overall students were pleased with the class.

This intermediate-level honors course in macroeconomics and the global economy, including topics in monetary and international economics, aims to provide a unified framework for understanding macroeconomic events and policy. The course analyzes the determinants and behavior of employment, production, demand and profits; inflation, interest rates, asset prices, and wages; exchange rates and international flows of goods and assets; including the interaction of the real economy with monetary policy and the financial system. 

Although some students found parts of the class too theoretical, other parts, such including the current events analysis, helped balance the course. Students appreciated the international focus of the class, and one student noted, “Without a doubt, my understanding of macroeconomics has expanded significantly after taking this class.” 

Students almost invariably praised Professor Souleles, emphasizing his commitment to the students and their comprehension of the class material. Students described him with words like “amazing,” “phenomenal” “incredible,” “outstanding,” and “passionate.” According to one student, he “genuinely cares about his students and their intellectual development” and was “excellent at explaining course concepts.” 

Most agreed that the lecture supplements were helpful and that exams were challenging but fair. Others mentioned that the pace of the course was right on target. “The class was always interesting and I enjoyed coming to class every day we had it,” one student commented. “And this is from someone who doesn't like finance that much.”
